segments.text: So basically what you were going to do is get right in the middle.
You were going to take your tanks.
I was going to go in right after dark when they're going through this town and going on across the bridge.
I'm coming in right in behind them and follow them right across the bridge.
Wouldn't they know that you weren't one of them?
Not necessarily.
Why not?
Because they're moving, you know, and a tank is a tank, you know, in the dark.
Uh-huh.
You see?
Well, wouldn't the last tank, wouldn't he know that he was supposed to be the last?
He doesn't know.
The rear end has been cut up back there.
As far as he knows, there's another hundreds of them behind him.
I'm going to be those vehicles.
Jim Starr is going to cut the tail off his column and start shooting the hell out of them out there.
Well, we got into town.
And we got in the damnedest knockdown and brawl you have ever seen.
We were shooting each other up at 20 feet.
At 20 feet?
20 feet.
Here comes a tank.
Here comes a tank around this corner of the building here, and I'm right there, and I'm killing him there, and he's shooting at my guys over here and back and forth, and it is a shambles.
Ended up that they started giving up, and...

I ended up down just at the face of the bridge with a Panzerfaust busted in my face off the cobblestone, cut all the way through here, through here, all through here, piece resting against a jugular vein, machine pistol bullet in the knee.
And you were inside the tank?
I was out on the ground leading the tranq on foot with infantry.
because you're in close quarters in the village, I mean in the town, so you've got to get out of that on foot.
How can you even shoot that close?
Huh?
How can you even shoot a tank that close?
Bang, point blank.
Oh, yeah.
One tank shot another one in the rear from about five or six feet.
One of my tanks shot a German.

This German comes squealing out in front of him in the street, and he just, German come out like that, and by the time my gunner could shoot, I can't remember, I think it was one of them, Jack Knight, Jack Knight's company, Jack Knight had one of them.
He just shot him right in the rear and set it on fire.
The town was all on fire.
By this time, I mean, my God, we were shooting each other up in there.
And they blew the damn bridge on us.
Oh, they did?
Yeah.
Blew the damn bridge on us.
How many tanks did you lose?
I don't know.
I didn't have anybody killed.
I think I was the most seriously wounded.
And, uh,
I might have had a couple of things with tracks and stuff blown off of them, but I didn't have any total losses.
Germans were, at this point of war, their fighting capability had deteriorated to the point where it was a heyday for me, you see.
And they were trying to get away from you.
Oh, hell, they didn't want to fight.
They wanted to get away.
And they only fight because of honor and because they thought I was going to kill them all.
They said, well, hell, I might as well try to kill him.
He's going to try to kill me.
I wasn't going to try to kill him unless he fired first because what the hell do you get out of that?
So you were hoping when you went into that town that they'd surrender?
Yeah, and they did after they'd fired several shots, but I wanted that bridge.
But hell, if I could have got that bridge, I just probably said to hell with Eisenhower and everybody else.
And this might have been a very historical case of the commander not having received word and damn if he didn't stagger in and take Berlin.
Now you're going to withdraw him or what are you going to do?
And what a hell of an episode that had made in the history of the world.
Huh?
Isn't that something?
I wanted that bridge, and nobody said I couldn't take it.
The division commander had said, grab the bridge on the Elbe.
That, to me, went, he's going on to Berlin.
We had no idea then that we weren't going to Berlin.
That was the name of the game, to get the war over.
So...
So tell me about your wound.
Were you sent back?
I was sent back to the 4th Station Hospital in country and I talked my way out of there in a few days.
What was wrong with you?
I had been cut, this lip had been cut all the way through, all the way through to my teeth.
I had been cut in here above my eye.
This is a shell fragment from that rocket that they fired at the tank, and I was out in front of the tank, and there was a piece against the jugular vein.
I was just bleeding a lot, mad.
It just cut that wide open and cut down through here on my chin, and I guess I'd
been all right except until that machine pistol bullet hit me in the knee and then knocked me down.
And the artillery battalion commander had gotten up then, it was about midnight, Colonel Berlin, a lieutenant colonel working for me.
I was still a major then, I hadn't been promoted, I was on the list to get promoted in a matter of a few days.
But he drug me up in a doorway and they put me on a jeep.
I'd evacuate sometime during the night.
And I went back and got patched up.
This machine pistol bullet was in the cartilage.
And they said, yeah, we'll just leave it there until it starts bothering you.
It's still there today.
It's still there.
Machine pistol bullet, yeah.
Small .25 caliber machine pistol bullet that they fired out of a window and knocked me down.
It made me very unhappy.
And, uh,
That pretty much was it except I went back to my unit and then we withdrew to Brunswick.
And then we waited until the Germans took Berlin.
The Russians took Berlin.
And then the 2nd Armored Division was the honored division to occupy Berlin first for the American forces.
And that was in September and the division commander said to me,

don't you think we've been over here about three years now don't you think it's time to go home and I said if you say so sir and he said well where do you want to go I said I do not know he said well I'll tell you where you're going I'm going to become the commandant of the cavalry school at General I.D.
White
and said, you're coming along to command a cavalry regiment, a mechanized cavalry regiment at Fort Riley, Kansas.
He said, how do you like that?
And I said, anything you say.
So I came back home and I saw Mrs. Hollingsworth and our young son, who was born in 1942.
And we spent four years at Fort Riley, Kansas.
And I guess that ought to kind of wrap things up for today.
Yes, that's a good place to stop for today.
This is our second interview with General Hollingsworth.
And last, yesterday, we left off right at the end of the Second World War.
And I was wondering, at this time, were you interested in first going and fighting the Japanese?
Or second, had you at
while demobilization was taking place, had you started thinking about perhaps leaving the service, or had you made up your mind to have it occur by then?
Let's start with a Japanese question.
A Japanese question, uh, I think it resolved itself around the fact that, uh, I had been away from home almost three years, and, uh,
I had been wounded a total of five times.
I had been away from home almost three years in war in Africa and Sicily and all across Europe.
As far as I was concerned, my part of the war was over.
The Japanese conflict was still going on, and if I had been asked to go to assist in the final days of the war in the Pacific, I would have gone.
I do believe that I felt some serious obligation to my family
and I think that the Army would have had to ask me to go instead of me volunteering to go.
I had one final wrap-up on the European conflict in World War II.
I make reference to the last battle by Cornelius Ryan.

We have not covered certain exploits in here which are authenticated and recorded in his book, so I refer you to that for some incidental battles such as I may have led the last charge with tanks in the history of our
country and I recommend that to you for reference material.
Would you explain what we were talking about yesterday on the Elbe?
Other incidents where I lined up tanks on a reverse slope of a hill and charged heavy anti-tank guns as the old cavalry led the old cavalry charge.
That detail is in the book and it can be read there.
We were talking about the Japanese.
The second question I believe you asked was had I given any thought and consideration to career.
At that time, I had been honored with a distinguished service cross, four silver stars for gallantry, and four bronze stars for valour, and had been wounded five times, had five purple hearts,
and was still alive and healthy so I had commanded a force of more than 3,000 people by the time I was 25 years old in battle and battle is a real test of man so I felt that I had met the
test a man in the face of enemy fire on the battlefield and that if I'd been able to do that I felt that maybe I owed something more to my country by serving in the Army wherein I could
further responsibility to my country and also for the training and leading of young men.
And I know of no other, no other profession that allows a man who is interested in people, I know of no other profession that offers the opportunity that the Army does for leadership
association with new people, the training, the building of them, the watching of them grow, and leading them in battle.
And it's an awesome responsibility.
When you think about, as I said yesterday, the responsibilities of an officer.
assignment which I ended my career was in command of 250,000 men and responsible for the defense of a whole country and 37 million people I'm referring to the Republic of Korea.
That's an awesome responsibility.
with little compensation, with little compensation, money-wise, financially-wise.
So, to live with that awesome responsibility on a meager salary is one hell of a sacrifice and one hell of a responsibility in which
The United States Army provided me that opportunity.
My country provided me that opportunity, and I shall be forever grateful.
You never entertained the thought.
While demobilization was going on in late 1945 and throughout 1946, it must have been somewhat of a discouraging episode
career people?
You never entertained the thought of leaving the service and going like most of them back to civilian life?
I think that you evaluate all of the different aspects of life at a signal point
in history, as was the case in which we're discussing at the end of World War II.
I looked at several alternatives.
The first one was to go to medical school because I thought that I could offer a service again to people
because to me the only thing important in our world is people and a good physician who is dedicated to his profession provides a great service to people.
I was offered without any
assistance from anyone, I was offered a job to start out as a district manager of a metropolitan life insurance company in one of the largest cities here in Texas.
And not knowing anything about the insurance business, I could not see myself on the street corner begging people to buy an insurance policy.
And that was my outlook on the insurance business at that time.
So I very quickly cast that away.
General Motors, as a result of my experience in the field of maintenance, had made offers to me to go to
Cadillac Motor Car Company who was building our light tanks and light anti-aircraft weapons at the time.

I gave that serious thought, but then on the other hand, my thoughts come back to people and if I had been involved in General Motors, I would have been involved in the production of materialistic things.
and materialistic things are not important.
They can be made important only if they're used to enhance the welfare of people.
So as a tank and an airplane and an artillery piece, it is a worthless piece of material if it's standing idle and isn't being used
And we avoid that aspect of things during peacetime by using it to train soldiers so that when they go to battle they can live on the battlefield.
So that's an example of my view of how to use a materialistic thing, make it important to enhance the welfare of an individual and the country.
those auctions and I always came back to the profession that I had been successful to date with at that time and that was the military and I guess that Miss Hollingsworth
It was a great encouragement to me.
She said to me, whatever you decide to do, I will be right by your side.
And when I said that I felt that our, the state, and the profession of arms, I believe she felt very confident about our future.
I was wondering about another thing.
In July of 1945,
You were promoted to Lieutenant Colonel.
Throughout the next year after the war was over, a number of officers lost rank, lost a grade, and that was almost pro-forma, but you didn't.
You were one of the most junior Lieutenant Colonels in the Army,

and you didn't lose you weren't demoted back to a major like why that's phenomenal why was that why did you maintain your colonelcy well out of some 15 to 20,000 or 30,000 that lost their rank 1100 of us retained our rank
Out of 30,000, 1,100 stayed the same, right?
And I can't explain that except that maybe my record had something to do with it.
I never did really know why.
why they did not demote the 1100, but of course we were very grateful for this.
We had very low pay, but you know we never really gave that too much thought at the time, and we stayed in our
Those 1100 stayed in that grade for a long, long time.
Oh yeah, you were in that grade for 11 years.
Yes, a long, long time.
So, I guess that your war record and the honors that had been bestowed on you during those combat
had a lot to do with it.
Okay, let's now move to Talvery School.
You were there from August 1945 until July of 1949 in two different capacities, commanding officer of the school troops regiment and an instructor.
Why were you an instructor second, commanding officer first?
The commandant, General I.D.
White, was my division commander, as I referred to earlier.
And since I had been in command for a long time, one of the most difficult units to command in our military is a regiment or a battalion or a unit that supports the school.

because of the great demands from all the instructors in the different departments, Department of Weapons, Department of Tactics, Department of Automotive, Department of Communication, Department of Electronics, all these departments and the department heads all placing demands on this regiment of about 2,200 people.
called the School Troop Regiment, actually.
It was organized as a cavalry regiment, mechanized cavalry regiment.
It was a very difficult thing to command, and an officer that had no command experience can find himself in deep trouble in the school with little support.
I think he felt that because of my command experience that I was the guy that should run that.
I stayed there some time.

The size of the military began to decrease and it came back to about a battalion size because they decided that's all they needed because the student load had been reduced as a result of the war being over and the Japanese conflict was over.
The foreign student requirement was dropping off.
They had quite a number of Chinese officers, South American officers, Canadians, Brits, and everybody from all over the world there as students.
That began to drop off.
The requirements decreased and the unit became a battalion size unit.
Then I was, I guess after 18 months or more, some point about that time, I then moved to become the Chief of Combined Arms Tactics in the Department of Tactics at the Cavalry School.
And I stayed there until a commanding general was sent to
command the Constabulary, which was more or less the occupation forces in West Germany.
Before we get to West Germany, I want to ask you a couple questions about this period 1945 to 1949.
One thing that happened was that the services were changed quite a bit.
the Air Corps became the Air Force and the Joint Chiefs of Staff was set up and everything.
What were your feelings about that?
Well, it was the sort of thing that I felt was coming along primarily because of the size of the remaining Air Corps.
and because of its responsibilities it just appeared to me that that was an evolutionary thing and that it was coming and you'll note that we have patterned a lot of our lifestyles and a lot of our
culture and a lot of our way of life after that Western Europe, and you'll find that the Luftwaffe was a separate arm and RAF was a separate arm.
Not so in the Soviet, but we don't, never have, and I
hope never will pattern anything after the soldiers.
Now what about another thing during this time Harry Truman issued an executive order integrating the Armed Forces blocks instead of in separate units would be integrated units.
What were your feelings about that?
Well I'd expressed my feelings back when I was ten years old and I had no problem with that.
We had many

many failures within the military of solid black units and so you always try to work your way away from the failure and I thought that that would be a good move to split everybody up and put a few here and a few there.
And I think that the Army, although President Truman, who I knew personally,
I think he kind of looked for the Army to set the example for this nation, and I think we have.
I think we have.
You said that you knew, when did you meet Truman?
Can you tell me about that?
Well, to sit down and talk to him personally was after he left the White House.
As I'd mentioned to you,
Mr. President Kennedy had appointed me with approval, of course, of Mr. Magnum there as Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense when I was a colonel, and that's a political appointee, civilian slot.
And the occasion arose for me to go visit with

sit down and visit with President Truman was when President Kennedy was trying to influence a piece of legislation which was going to have a serious impact on his authority unless we kill the legislation on the president's authority.
And through my research, well, I had found that a like incident had occurred during President Truman's tenure and that we had been able to beat the legislation at that time.
and that President Kennedy dispatched me, I was in the Department of Defense, to go visit with.

Since we could not find any reference in the files in the White House to this particular matter, which had occurred several years back, President Kennedy asked Mr. McNamara to dispatch me to sit down with
President Truman out in Independence and see if we could put this together and seek his support and also his documentation on this during his time.
And I called President Truman
He wasted no time saying, Mr. Secretary, you come straight away.
He said, we'll sit down and iron this thing out.
He said, how is Jack?
And I said, well, Mr. President, I don't see President Kennedy very often, but I said, I think he's doing great.
He said, I do too.
And you come on out.
So I went on out.
Sit down, and I spent an hour and a half with him.
still working as if he was in the White House answering calls from all over the country and giving people hell when they needed it over the phone.
And I recall one conversation, someone had called him, and I said, shall I leave, Mr. President?
He said, no, you stay where you are.
I said, I want you to hear what's going on here.
So a telephone call, he said, he answered back to whoever it was, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes.
Then all at once he says, and by God, now you listen to me.
You don't tell me, I'll tell you.
So he was still very much informed, I'd say, at that point in time.
By his assistance, I brought the material back, got a copy of the matter, and we were able to keep the presidential authority in order.
I'm wondering what we're talking about.
We were talking about the blacks and then we were talking about Mr. Truman.
Now let's go back to Germany.
In August of 1949, you were assigned commander of the Special Troops Regiment in the U.S. Constabulary.
Now this is during the Berlin blockade.
What impact did that have on your job?
There was a great enhancement of security all in Western Europe because we had no idea at the time what the outcome of this blockade was going to be.
We knew the Soviet strength and the location of their units in East Germany.
We knew the strength and composition of the East Germans, Poles, Czechs, Hungarians, and the members of the Warsaw Pact.
But here we were in Western Europe with a strength of about 55,000.
I'm talking about combat troops.
We had the 1st Division, the big red one, who was later, as you know, my favorite division.
And we had the Constabulary, which was made up of armored cavalry regiments, and there were some separate battalions.
And we had quite a sector.
We had from the Austrian border, all of the Austrian border facing West Germany, the Czech border,
and then part of the East German border up as far as it exists right today, near Castle.
Well, that was an awesome responsibility for only 55,000 troops.
So, it was a sort of thing where you planned and watched very carefully about what you were going to do about a big headquarters in Frankfurt,
in Heidelberg and a big headquarters in Stuttgart, which we were a part of.
It was an intense period which really, I think, triggered a build-up to the strength that you have over today.
Another thing that influenced subsequent action that influenced the intensity of things there was 5 o'clock on the morning of the 25th of June 1950 when the Koreans come charging across the DMZ
And my God, people are trying to get out of Europe to go to the Korean conflict, and we were faced with a conflict there.
The intensity of the Warsaw Pact was exacerbated by excessive patrolling and activity all along the front.
I remember very well at 2 o'clock in the morning, I had a flash message from a cavalry troop at Hof, Germany, and I was called to the headquarters.
At this point in time, I was chief of operations for Seventh Army.
Now I've been growing up to Seventh Army.
I was chief of operations in the G3 section.
A duty officer called me two o'clock in the morning, can you please come to headquarters, we have a flash top secret message from the front.
I jumped in my clothes, I lived ten minutes away from headquarters.
Got to headquarters, got in there, looked at the message.
I called my boss, who was a brigadier general, and I said,
keep a watchful eye on this situation, and he said, well, I'll be there soon.
I said, okay.
We spent the rest of the night there, and during the night, we prepared a message for the Army commander to send back to the United States to evacuate our civilians out of there, civilian dependents.
What did the flash message say?
The flash message was that there was a Soviet tank company
had gathered itself up just across from a crossing point.
And we had one small cavalry platoon there.
That's all.
That's all we could afford.
They had a whole tank company of thirteen tanks.
And they had moved down there and they were making signs of coming across the border.
And if they had, that would have started it, and we had nothing to stop it with.
Our little cavalry platoon would have been eaten up in a few minutes, and here they come.
So you don't want dependents around in the country when that does, because dependents are a great hindrance to you, because it's very difficult to get a human being to
to leave his wife or children unknowingly what's going to happen to them and go out to fight and hoping that somebody else is going to take care of them, he's usually going to say, to hell with that.
I'm not going to leave them to go anywhere until I get my family out of here.
And then after I do that, I'll come back and fight.
Well, you've got to have all of them say that, then you've lost the battle.
Oh, for sure.
So that's a trouble with dependents in an area which may be threatened.
But it was an intense period, no question about that.
Now NATO was formed at this time, North Atlanta Treaty Organization in 1949.
Did you have any dealings with that?
The only dealings I had was to work out war plans with the French and to conduct exercises.
with them and where they were participants.
And I was extremely worried about that because the communist infiltration into France at that time was pretty strong.
And I was really very hesitant to pass on top secret information during training exercises, joint exercises, to the French.
Did you pass on that information?
Yes, I did.
Yes, I did.
like it at the time, as it was.
What did you think of the quality of the French?
I thought the French were no better than they were, I felt, in World War II, which wasn't very far off.
The French suffered a disastrous slaughter of their leadership during World War I.
was questioned the recovery today.
Questioned the recovery today.
Their tactics during World War II, imagine no line.
Imagine no line complex.
We must never allow that to happen in this country.
We just can't allow it to happen.
I'm afraid it still exists in the minds of some of the French.
I visited some of their commanders in 1976, 77, and
I was impressed with the fact that there are a few old-time World War II leaders still around who know what war is all about, but their armed forces have been treated very shabbily
from the standpoint of conventional capability.
I doubt that they could fight more than 30 days sustained action without losing a hell of a lot of equipment that couldn't be replaced and also running out of ammunition in many instances.
They have spent their money on nukes.
And kind of like this country, no one can ever afford to have a nuclear war, but on the other hand, you can't afford not to have that option since the other guys got the option.
But in my private view, it'll be way beyond the 50th century before anybody ever fires a nuclear weapon for anything other than making electricity.
And that we ought to get.
